title: Hierarchical Models: Multi-level Priors
contentHtml:
Hierarchical models are a powerful tool in Bayesian statistics, allowing us to model complex relationships between variables at multiple levels.

By using multi-level priors and random effects, we can account for variability within groups and capture higher-order dependencies.
name: Hierarchical Model Formula
intuition: Hierarchical models are useful when we have multiple observations within groups and want to account for both within-group and between-group variability.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the hierarchical structure with multiple levels of grouping

intuition: By sharing parameters across groups, we can capture commonalities and reduce the number of hyperparameters needed.

title: Hierarchical Models: Multi-level Priors
contentHtml: In Bayesian statistics, hierarchical models allow us to incorporate prior knowledge about groups or clusters of data. This is particularly useful when dealing with nested or grouped data.
name: Product of Priors

problemHtml: Suppose we're analyzing exam scores for students in different schools. We want to model the average score per school.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Define a prior distribution for each school's average score", "mathHtml": "\[p(θ_i|α, β) = N(α, β^{-1})\]", "explanation": "We assume the prior is normally distributed with mean α and precision β."} ],

subject: statistics
title: Hierarchical Models in Bayesian Statistics
contentHtml:
Hierarchical models are a cornerstone of Bayesian statistics, allowing us to model complex systems with multiple levels of structure.

By incorporating multi-level priors and partial pooling, we can account for random effects and uncertainty at each level.
name: Hierarchical Linear Model
variants: [ {"latex": "\[y_{ij} \sim N(X_j\beta + Zu_{ij}, \sigma^2)\]", "description": "Generalized hierarchical model for multiple observations"} ] },
problemHtml: Suppose we're analyzing student test scores across different schools and classes.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Specify the prior distribution for school-level means", "mathHtml": "\[u_i \sim N(0, \tau^2)\]", "explanation": "We assume each school has its own mean, with some shared uncertainty."} ],
intuition: Hierarchical models help us separate signal from noise by accounting for the structure of our data.
realWorldApplications: Analyzing student performance across schools and classes
